title: Santa Claus Is Coming to Town
author: J. Fred Coots and Haven Gillespie

content.text: It was a chilly winter evening in the bustling town of Sombertown, where the snowflakes fell gently from the sky like tiny ballerinas.
The townspeople scurried about, busy with their holiday preparations, while the sound of laughter and caroling filled the air.
But amidst all the joy and cheer, there was one person who didn't quite fit in – a jolly old man with a heart of gold and a beard as white as snow.
His name was Kris Kringle, but the world would soon come to know him as Santa Claus.
Kris lived in a small workshop on the outskirts of town, where he spent his days crafting toys for the children of Sombertown.
He was a toymaker, just like his father and his father's father before him.
But Kris's toys were different – they were made with love, care, and a dash of magic.
As the holiday season approached, Kris's workshop became a flurry of activity, with wooden toys, dolls, and trains taking shape under his skilled hands.
One day, as Kris was busy putting the finishing touches on a particularly intricate wooden rocking horse, there was a knock at the door.
It was a young girl named Jessica, who had wandered away from her parents in the market square.
She had heard stories of the kind old toymaker who lived on the outskirts of town and was determined to meet him.
Kris welcomed Jessica into his workshop, where she was amazed by the array of toys on display.
As they sipped hot cocoa and nibbled on cookies, Kris told Jessica the story of how he became a toymaker.
He spoke of his childhood, growing up in a family of skilled craftsmen, and of the joy he found in bringing happiness to children through his toys.
Jessica listened with wide eyes, feeling as though she had stumbled upon a treasure trove of wonder and magic.
Just then, a loud, gruff voice boomed from outside the workshop. "Kris Kringle, you're a menace!
Your toys are a distraction, a frivolous waste of time!" It was Burgermeister Meisterburger, the grumpiest, most miserly man in all of Sombertown.
He had outlawed toys and fun in the town, deeming them a hindrance to productivity and progress.
Kris, however, was not one to be deterred.

He stood tall, his eyes twinkling with mirth, and said, "Ah, but toys bring joy, and joy is what makes life worth living!" The Burgermeister scowled, but Kris could see the faintest glimmer of a smile behind his gruff exterior.
As the days passed, Kris's toys became more and more popular, with children from all over Sombertown sneaking into the workshop to catch a glimpse of the jolly old toymaker at work.
The Burgermeister, however, grew more and more disgruntled, determined to put an end to Kris's "nonsense" once and for all.
On Christmas Eve, as the snow fell gently over Sombertown, Kris's workshop was busier than ever.
Toys were piled high, and the sound of laughter and music filled the air.
Jessica, who had become Kris's closest friend, helped him load the toys into a great, gleaming sleigh.
As they worked, Kris told her of his dream – to bring joy and happiness to children all around the world, not just in Sombertown.
Just as they were finishing up, the Burgermeister appeared, his face redder than a ripe tomato.
"You'll never deliver those toys, Kris Kringle!" he shouted, his voice echoing through the night air.
But Kris just chuckled and said, "Oh, I think I will, my dear Burgermeister.
You see, I have a few friends who are willing to lend a hand."  With a jingle of bells and a flash of magic, a team of reindeer appeared, their antlers shining in the moonlight.
Kris climbed into the sleigh, with Jessica by his side, and they took off into the night sky, leaving the Burgermeister to grumble and scowl in their wake.
As they soared above the town, Kris and Jessica delivered toys to children everywhere, their laughter and joy infectious.
The Burgermeister, however, was left to ponder the true meaning of Christmas – and the magic of a jolly old man with a heart of gold.
Years went by, and Kris's legend grew.
Children from far and wide came to visit the old toymaker, now known as Santa Claus.
And though the Burgermeister never did come to appreciate the joy of toys, he did learn to respect the kindness and generosity of the man who brought happiness to so many.
As for Kris, he continued to live in his workshop, surrounded by the magic of the holiday season.
And every year, on Christmas Eve, he would climb into his sleigh, with Jessica by his side, and deliver toys to children all around the world, spreading joy and happiness wherever he went.
